Asus opens the day by redefining what a laptop is even supposed to be. The ROG Zephorus Duo doesn't aim to look familiar, and that's intentional. Instead of one display, two full-size OLED screens sit stacked, turning the device into a portable command center rather than a traditional laptop. One screen handles the main task while the other manages everything around it. Editing tools, timelines, chats, controls, or reference material. The keyboard detaches and snaps back magnetically. Power comes from modern Intel processors and high-end graphics. But performance isn't the headline. Flexibility is. This laptop is made for people who need to do five things at once. Even though it's a bit thicker than a normal laptop, it stays cool and has a port for every cable you own. As ASUS didn't make this to look like every other computer, they built it to show that you can take a full two-screen setup anywhere you go. John Deere completely stole the spotlight at CES 2026. You might expect to see new phones or gaming laptops at CES, but John Deere proved that a massive autonomous tractor is actually the most high-tech gadget on the floor. They aren't just showing off big machines. They are showing off intelligent systems. These tractors and harvesters drive themselves using smart cameras to see the field and AI brains to make decisions every second. Instead of a farmer having to sit in a cab for 12 hours straight, these machines handle the exhausting work without ever getting tired. Even in remote fields, these machines stay connected to the internet. This allows them to talk to each other, share data, and even fix their own problems before they happen. It's like having a team of robots that learns how to do a better job with every single pass. While John Deere is automating the farm, Razer is bringing AI directly to your desk. They just revealed Project Ava, and it looks like something straight out of a sci-fi movie. Instead of being just another app on your screen, Project Ava lives inside a sleek, glowing glass cylinder. Inside that tube, a 5-in holographic character floats in the air, moving and reacting like a real person. It's equipped with high-tech cameras and microphones, so it can actually see and hear you in real time. Ava isn't just there to look cool, though. It understands the vibe of your room. Now, the conversation moves to one of the most common daily struggles, cooking. After long days, standing at a stove, tracking steps, watching heat, and constantly stirring is often what pushes people toward takeout or frozen meals. That's where NSH comes in. Think of NSH as a robot chef that lives on your kitchen counter. It's a smart machine designed to take over the hardest parts of cooking. The process is simple. You load your chopped ingredients into trays, pick a recipe, and walk away. Inside, AI cameras and sensors monitor the heat and timing while the robot handles all the stirring. It's constantly making adjustments so your food never burns and always tastes fresh. At CES 2026, Ford proved they aren't interested in flashy hype. Instead of promising magic self-driving cars immediately, they unveiled a realistic road map for eyes off driving by 2028. The secret is their new vehicle brain, a powerful computer they built inhouse to control everything from AI to sensors. by designing their own software and hardware. Ford has tighter control over how their cars see and think. This isn't a science experiment. It's a shift to making vehicles that truly understand their environment. Ford is turning your car from a simple machine into a smart partner you can trust. Transportation takes a sharper turn with Tensor's Robocar. This is not an electric vehicle with autonomy added later. It is built around AI from the ground up. Massive onboard compute power allows the robot to process camera, radar, and LAR data simultaneously. Steering, braking, perception, and charging are all controlled by intelligent systems with layered redundancy. The vehicle can even charge itself autonomously, removing another human task. This electric vehicle is designed for private ownership and commercial deployment at the same time. But what if the robot wasn't a car or a tractor, but something you actually wore? Their new H1 Pro is a modular exoskeleton, which is basically a smart suit that you wear to give your muscles a boost. What makes it cool is that it's like Lego for your legs. Deffy pushes that idea further down to the feet. Walking may look simple, but it requires constant muscle engagement and balance. Deffy's robotic sneakers add powered assistance with every step, adjusting automatically based on gate and effort. At lower settings, movement feels lighter and easier. At higher levels, users feel a noticeable boost in speed and power. What begins as mobility support quickly enters performance territory. Early testing already shows improved endurance and faster walking speeds. Dey isn't replacing muscles, it's extending them. This technology targets confidence, mobility, and eventually athletic enhancement. Personal mobility takes a more human- centered form with the Strut Evan. Instead of feeling like a medical device, this EV1 feels like independence. Sensors, AI navigation, and assisted driving work together to reduce collision anxiety and expand movement. The EV1 follows, guides, and adapts to its user. slopes, uneven ground, and tight spaces become manageable. The system breaks down into portable components, making transport easier. Mobility shifts from limitation to confidence. ULS Robotics debuted the Vatrix at CES 2026 to prove that powers suits aren't just for movies. It's a lightweight exoskeleton, only about 6 lb, that learns your specific walking style. Instead of feeling like a stiff machine, it uses a floating hip joint that lets you do deep squats or long strides naturally. It's designed for hikers and travelers, giving you a 15-m power boost, so you can explore farther without your legs getting tired. Wheel Move arrived at CES with a simple but life-changing attachment for manual wheelchairs. In just a few seconds, this 20 lb motor snaps onto the front of a standard chair and lifts the small front wheels off the ground. It instantly turns a manual chair into an electric one that can handle grass, gravel, and hills. It doesn't replace the chair you already own. It just gives you the freedom to go where standard wheels usually get stuck. To close out the show, the big three of home tech reminded us that the screens and sounds we use everyday still matter. Davidbot uses advanced facial animation systems that sync speech with micro expressions. When the robot smiles, muscles around the eyes react naturally. When it pauses, the face settles instead of freezing. This solves one of robotics's biggest problems, the uncanny valley. Built on the Ask Arya platform, the system adjusts tone and expression based on detected emotion. It is positioned for entertainment, hospitality, and customer-f facing roles. The result feels less like a machine responding and more like a presence reacting in real time. If realism was one extreme, raw physical ability was the other. Engine AI showcased two humanoids that focus entirely on motion and strength. The PM01 is a lightweight embodied agent designed for realworld environments like malls, stations, and guided tours. Movement is smooth, controlled, and practical. Then comes the T800. This full scale humanoid delivers up to 450 Newton meter of torque per joint and 14,000 watts of instantaneous power. That level of force allows sprinting, jumping, and combat style movement. Instead of slow mechanical steps, the T800 moves like a trained athlete. Tombot presented Jenny, a robotic companion created for seniors with dementia and individuals dealing with anxiety. Jenny uses nine servo motors to control subtle movements, ears, head tilt, eyebrows, and tail. The design was developed with Jim Henson's Creature Shop, giving it lifelike motion instead of rigid animation. Capacitive touch sensors allow the robot to respond when petted or held when interaction stops. Jenny reacts with gentle movement to re-engage. Priced around $1,500, it replaces neither therapy nor care, but offers emotional presence for people unable to maintain a real pet. Displays took a major leap forward with Lenovo's ThinkPad Rollable XD. At first glance, it looks like a standard 13.3 inch laptop. Then the screen expands upward into a full 16 inch vertical workspace. The rollable panel is powered by dual motors and steel cable support to keep the display flat and rigid. Unlike earlier concepts, there's no warping or distortion. Part of the screen wraps around the exterior when closed, enabling a world-facing display for notifications or schedules. This design removes the need for external monitors while keeping the device travel friendly. It's a practical evolution of foldables focused on productivity rather than spectacle. CES always delivers unexpected products. One of the most talked about was the Brolon Clear X, an AI powered shoe cleaning system. Shoes are scanned internally to identify material types like leather, suede or mesh. Based on that data, the system selects a cleaning and drying cycle automatically. The core technology uses micro nano bubbles which penetrate fabric without soaking it. This removes dirt while preserving structure and glue. With an estimated price between $500 and $800, it targets collectors rather than casual users. for sneaker preservation. It may solve a problem most didn't know could be automated. Behind many of these machines is one key player, Qualcomm at CES. The company unveiled the Dragon Wing IQ10 chip built specifically for physical AI systems. The chip features an 18 core Orion CPU and delivers 700 tops of AI performance. That's more than 10 times the power of most AI laptops. It supports up to 20 simultaneous camera inputs, allowing robots to see, reason, and act in real time. Qualcomm pairs this with a visual language action model, meaning robots understand what objects are and how they should be handled. The X4 represents a shift from proving flight is possible to proving it can be safe and accessible. Minimalism took an extreme form with the HP Elite Board G1A. There is no separate PC. The keyboard is the computer. Inside its 0.7 in chassis sits an AMD Ryzen AI 300 series processor, cooling system, speakers, and microphones. The internal design is modular, allowing RAM and storage upgrades. This concept brings back the spirit of early home computers, updated for cloud workflows and AIdriven productivity. The cube uses multimodal AI to identify objects and explain them through stories and facts. Instead of screenbased interaction, it encourages realworld exploration. The flexible silicone mask uses 630 nm red light and 830 nm near infrared light wavelengths known to support collagen production and skin repair. An integrated microcircuit controls exposure time and intensity to prevent overuse. Unlike rigid masks, this design conforms to facial contours for even treatment.
